thread.title: ZINK: 'Fast' Jack Beckman gets back into the thick of Funny Car title points race
thread.title_full: ZINK: 'Fast' Jack Beckman gets back into the thick of Funny Car title points race - Press Enterprise

author: The Press-Enterprise
title: ZINK: 'Fast' Jack Beckman gets back into the thick of Funny Car title points race
text:
STAFF COLUMNIST
Published: Oct. 8, 2015 7:29 p.m. Norco’s “Fast” Jack Beckman called his shot last weekend, winning at the NHRA Keystone Nationals in record-breaking fashion and pulling to 16 points behind Del Worsham in the Funny Car championship points race.
Beckman, who set the national elapsed time record (3.897 seconds) for the third time in 2015, won his seventh race of the season and became the first Funny Car driver to set the Funny Car ET record three times in a season since Cruz Pedregon in 1998.
Facing the possiblity of being eliminated from the NHRA Countdown to the Championship, Beckman and his crew put together another memorable weekend to pull right back into the thick of the Funny Car class championship race.
"Maple Grove might be national-record type of conditions,” said Beckman, heading into last weekend’s Keystone Nationals. “We basically put ourselves in a position where we're going to need to set a record and win the race to get back in this.
“Don't count us out, by a long shot.”
True to his word, Beckman and crew dialed a car that raced back to the front the points pack and re-ignited his chances to win his second career Funny Car World Championship. Beckman, who won his previous championship in 2012, was in a two-year winless slump until being paired with crew chief Jimmy Prock and crew.
“When qualifying got shortened because of the weather to one session, I thought that the national record was going to be off the table,” Beckman said during a Wednesday teleconference with the media. “I don't know that I could have hoped for the outcome that we got where we actually made up 103 points, which is slightly more than five rounds, on Del, and I think it just basically put us right back in the championship.”
Now with three races left – the Texas Fall Nationals (Oct. 15-18), the Toyota Nationals in Las Vegas (Oct. 29-Nov. 1) and the Auto Club Finals in Pomona (Nov. 12-15) – Beckman is right back where he wants to be, closing in on another world championship.
HOEFER HAS CAREER WEEKEND CW Hoefer of Calimesa used strategy and guile to outrace best friend Jack Swanson of Yucaipa to win the in the Sportsman Class final at last Sunday’s Summit Showdown, capping Hoefer’s career-best weekend of racing during the two-day NHRA Summit Racing Series Pacific Division Finals weekend at Auto Club Dragway in Fontana.
Hoefer, along with class winners Brian Fritz (Super Pro), Tony Marconi (Pro ET), Don Caesar (Motorcycle) and Phil Watkins (Pro ET) move on to race at the NHRA National Championship next month during the NHRA Finals weekend at Auto Club Raceway in Pomona.
Hoefer and the others will face off with winners from the six other NHRA Divisions at Pomona next month.
“This is by far the best weekend I’ve ever had in racing,” said Hoefer, who has lost out twice trying to get to Pomona. “I’ve been at this for 14 years and this is my first trip to the Nationals.”
Hoefer faced off with Swanson in the Sportsman final of Sunday’s Summit Showdown. Swanson took the early lead but ran too fast, giving Hoefer the win. Hoefer clocked in at 7.683 seconds at 83 miles per hour in his ’91 Firebird. Swanson went 7.896 on his 7.93 dial-in.
On Saturday, the Division 7 team from Auto Club Dragway won the team championship.
Hoefer, along with Brian Fritz, Tony Marconi, Don Caesar and Phil Watkins will all advance to the national championship where they will face off with winners from the six other NHRA Divisions across the country. All Summit Division Champions competing in Pomona will receive $3,000 from Summit Racing Equipment and will be competing for an additional $5,000 winner-take-all in each of the four classes.
Watkins, of Tucson, Ariz., led the list of winners from Saturday’s action along with Rialto’s Ryan Mangus, who led the Auto Club Dragway team to the team championship.
Watkins, who defeated Hoefer, took the win in Pro and will advance to the national championship via the wild card as the NHRA Pacific Division was drawn for the Pro Class earlier this year. Watkins used a holeshot to run down Hoefer, who was pulling double duty this weekend, driving in both the Sportsman and the Pro classes.
Mangus went seven rounds in Sportsman, defeating Nick Marconi in the final. His win helped lead the Auto Club Dragway team to the team championship by more than 20 points. Auto Club Dragway (84 points) defeated Auto Club Famoso Raceway of Bakerfield (60 points) and Sonoma Raceway (55).
GET STRAIGHT RHYTHM THIS WEEKEND Touted as the evolution of the sport of motocross, Red Bull Straight Rhythm is a competition that pits 24 of the top riders in the world in head-to-head, best-of-three racing on an “unwound” track (no turns) on the former horse racetrack at Pomona Fairplex, Friday and Saturday in Pomona.
The biggest names – Ryan Dungey, James Stewart, Ken Roczen, Marvin Musquin – will battle on a half-mile, straight rhythm section, which features 75 jumps and over 400 feet of whoops.
For more information go to www.redbull.com/straightrhythm.
